details.description: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing trivial benefits
details.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for trivial benefits
details.body:
All benefits are taxable, but you can ask HMRC to exclude some of them because theyâ€™re so small.

However, you still have tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations if you provide a benefit as a reward for service.

HMRC are more likely to agree to exclude a benefit as trivial if it’s connected with the employee’s welfare, such as a bunch of flowers for an employee who’s unwell.

To find out if a benefit is likely to be considered trivial by HMRC:

  1. Call the employer helpline.

  2. If the helpline advisor says that your benefit is likely to be considered trivial, contact your local employer office and ask them to confirm it in writing. The advisor will be able to give you contact details for your local office.

Employer helpline

Telephone: 08457 143 143
Textphone: 0845 602 1380

Monday to Friday 8am to 8pm
Saturday 8am to 4pm

What to report and pay

If HMRC says a benefit is trivial, you don’t have to report it. You don’t have to deduct and pay tax or National Insurance on the cost of it.

Technical guidance

Read more detailed information on particular benefits: treatment of benefits that are trivial in amount.
